p: At this point, it is worth mention L. galeobdolon L., commonly known as the â€˜yellow archangel, that has good potential as an ingredient for the preparation of functional foods. This species is a wildflower widespread in Europe and has been introduced elsewhere as a garden plant. An ethnobotanical study carried out on 49 edible wild plants traditionally harvested and consumed in a region of the Basque Country, Northern Spain, described the recreational use by children of nectar sucked from the base of L. galeobdolon flowers. Different benzoxazinoids (BXs), present as glucosides ( Figure 3), have been identified in the yellow archangel.
